content.description: The west face is narrow, 2-3 ft wide. The route follows the west face without the arete on the right or the easy stuff on the left. Good bailouts to the right and left for the timid. Nice balance and crimp problem.
content.location: it is on the left side of 5.8 Boulder, facing west.

content.description: Follows the left (west) arete using arete rules (left hand and foot on the left side); right hand and foot on the right. Good start, then it's over.

This is the south face of the 5.8 Boulder, just to the right of the southwest arete, starting with a good flake. Get established on the flake, figure out some foot voodoo magic, make another move on a good sidepull, and gain the massive positive ledge. Cruise the rest to the top.

The hardest part is the start due to the nature of the overhung foot area with limited foot options.

This has obviously been done before and is now being included as its own line to enjoy. If there's an established name/FA, chime in and I'll update as needed.
content.protection: A bouldering pad. It has an even landing zone.
content.location: Walk off to the northwest side of the boulder for an easy downclimb.

content.description: This is the South-Eastern arete on the block...Sit start on the east side of the block with your hands on the arete where a 4" ledge meets the east sdge of the south face. Pinch the arete all the way to the top without using any other holds. Fun to do if you are already there, not that great to fall off of.

Climb the east face of the 5.8 Boulder for a one/two move wonder starting from the obvious jug. Make due with minimal feet, and muscle yourself up and over.

If there's an original name, chime in and I'll update it.
content.protection: A crashpad, the landing is slanted with the hill but has a soft soil landing.
content.location: This problem is located on the east face of the 5.8 Boulder.
